install_python.name: Installing Python
install_python.definition: To make your computer understand Python, you need to install an interpreter. It translates your code into commands the processor can execute. Always download it from python.org.
install_python.dynamic_info: Version 3.12+ is current for Windows. Python is often pre-installed on macOS/Linux, but it should be updated.

types_list.desc: Make sure to check 'Add Python to PATH' during installation, otherwise commands won't work in terminal.
Best installed via Homebrew package manager or by downloading the .pkg file from the website.

slides.title: Official Website
slides.text: Visit python.org/downloads. The site will detect your OS automatically.

install_python.pro_tip: Avoid Python from the Microsoft Store; the official installer is more reliable for developers.
install_python.warning: Never delete the system Python on macOS/Linux — it might break your OS!

pycharm_setup.name: PyCharm Setup
pycharm_setup.definition: PyCharm is a powerful IDE. It checks for errors on the fly, helps you write code faster, and manages your projects. We will use the free Community Edition.
pycharm_setup.dynamic_info: PyCharm automatically creates virtual environments (venv) to keep project-specific libraries isolated.

types_list.desc: The free, open-source version for learning and pure Python development.
An isolated folder inside your project containing its own set of libraries and an interpreter.

slides.title: New Project
slides.text: Click 'New Project' and ensure 'New Virtualenv environment' is selected.

slides.title: Running Code
slides.text: Right-click your Python file and select 'Run' to execute your program.

pycharm_setup.pro_tip: Press Shift twice (Double Shift) to find any setting, file, or action within PyCharm.
pycharm_setup.warning: If your code doesn't run, check the 'Python Interpreter' in the project settings.

vars.name: Variables and Data Types
vars.definition: A variable is a place in the computer’s memory where a value is stored. You can imagine it as a box with a name on it. The name is the variable name, and what is inside is its value. Variables are used to store data that the program works with.
vars.dynamic_info: Python uses dynamic typing. This means you do not need to specify the type of a variable. When you write x = 5, Python understands that it is a number. If you later write x = 'hello', Python understands it is text. The type depends on the value.

types_list.desc: Integers are whole numbers. They are used for counting things like age or score.
Float numbers are used when precision is needed, like money or measurements.
A string is text. All strings must be written inside quotes.
Boolean values are True or False. They are used for conditions.
A list stores multiple values in one variable.
A tuple is like a list, but it cannot be changed.
A dictionary stores data as key-value pairs.
A set stores only unique values.

slides.title: What is a variable
slides.text: A variable is a named box that stores a value.

vars.pro_tip: Good variable names make code easy to understand.
vars.warning: Python is case-sensitive. age and Age are different variables.

io_basics.name: Interaction: print() and input()
io_basics.definition: For a program not to be 'isolated,' it needs to communicate with the user. The print() command displays information on the screen, while input() allows the user to type something and send it to the program.
io_basics.dynamic_info: The input() function always returns text (a string), even if you entered a number!

types_list.desc: Prints everything you pass in the parentheses to the console.
Pauses the program and waits until the user presses Enter.

slides.title: Print Function
slides.text: You can output multiple values separated by commas: print('Score:', score).

io_basics.pro_tip: Add an empty print() without arguments if you want to create an empty line break in the console.
io_basics.warning: Don't forget that after input(), the program 'freezes' until you provide data.

syntax_basics.name: Comments and Type Casting
syntax_basics.definition: Comments are notes for the programmer that the computer ignores. Type casting is converting one data type to another (for example, from text to a number).
syntax_basics.dynamic_info: Use the functions int(), float(), str() to force a type change.

types_list.desc: Anything after the hash mark is invisible to Python. Helps explain complex code.
Converts the string '10' into the actual number 10, which can be used for math.
Turns the number 500 into the text '500'. Useful for joining with other text.

slides.title: Why Comments are Needed
slides.text: They help you and your colleagues understand the code after some time has passed.

syntax_basics.pro_tip: Write comments as if the person reading your code is a violent psychopath who knows where you live.
syntax_basics.warning: Casting the text 'Hello' to a number using int() will cause an error because there are no digits in the word.

conditions.name: Conditions if / elif / else
conditions.definition: Conditional structures allow the program to make decisions. Code is executed only if the condition is True. If the first condition is false, the elif block is checked, and if nothing matches, the else block triggers.
conditions.dynamic_info: In Python, indentation (4 spaces) is not just a style choice, but a syntax requirement. Without them, the code won't understand what belongs to the condition.

types_list.desc: Basic condition check.
Additional check if the first condition fails.
Triggers in all other cases.

slides.title: Branching Logic
slides.text: The program chooses only one execution path from the proposed ones.

slides.title: Nesting
slides.text: You can put an if inside another if, but don't do it too often.

slides.title: Pass
slides.text: Use pass if a condition is needed, but you haven't decided what to write there yet.

conditions.pro_tip: Try to place the most likely condition first in the chain — this slightly speeds up the code.
conditions.warning: Don't forget to put a colon (:) at the end of every line with if, elif, and else!

operators.name: Logical Operators
operators.definition: The and, or, and not operators allow you to combine multiple conditions into one. This makes the program logic more flexible and complex.
operators.dynamic_info: Python uses 'lazy evaluation': in 'A and B', if A is false, B won't even be checked.

types_list.desc: True only when BOTH conditions are correct.
True if at least ONE condition is correct.
Inverts the result (turns True into False).

slides.title: Priorities
slides.text: First not is executed, then and, and finally or.

slides.title: Brackets
slides.text: Use brackets () to explicitly specify the order of condition checks.

slides.title: Shortcuts
slides.text: In Python, you can write 0 < x < 10 instead of (x > 0 and x < 10).

operators.pro_tip: and is like multiplication, or is like addition. This helps in remembering priorities.
operators.warning: Don't confuse 'and' with '&' — these are different operators (logical and bitwise).

loops.name: Loops for and while
loops.definition: Loops are needed for repeating actions. While works as long as the condition is true. For iterates over elements in a list or a range of numbers.
loops.dynamic_info: The for loop in Python is an iterator; it's very efficient when working with data collections.

types_list.desc: Repeats as long as the condition is true.
Iterates through the elements of a sequence.
break — exit the loop, continue — skip to the next iteration.

slides.title: Range
slides.text: range(5) will create numbers from 0 to 4. The last number is not included!

slides.title: Infinite Loop
slides.text: If the while condition is always True, the program will never stop.

slides.title: Else in Loop
slides.text: The else block after a loop will trigger if the loop finished without using break.

loops.pro_tip: Use for when you know the number of repetitions, and while when you don't.
loops.warning: Make sure the value changes inside while, otherwise you'll get a program 'hang'.

strings_basics.name: Strings in Python
strings_basics.definition: A string is a data type called str that is used to store text. Text means everything: words, sentences, numbers written as text, spaces, and special characters. For example: a person's name, a user message, a password, or a file path. In Python, strings must always be written inside single or double quotes.
strings_basics.dynamic_info: It is very important to remember: strings in Python are immutable. This means that after a string is created, you cannot change a single character inside it. Any “change” actually creates a new string.

types_list.desc: Creates a string and stores it in a variable. The text must be inside quotes.
Returns the number of characters in the string. Letters, digits, spaces, and symbols are all counted.
Combines two strings into one new string.
Repeats the string a specified number of times.

slides.title: What is a string
slides.text: Any text inside quotes in Python is a string.

strings_basics.pro_tip: Use f-strings to conveniently insert variables into text.
strings_basics.warning: Trying to change a string character directly will cause an error.

strings_index.name: String indexes and slices
strings_index.definition: Each character in a string has its own number called an index. Indexing starts from 0. This means the first character has index 0, the second has index 1, and so on. Slices allow you to get a part of a string.
strings_index.dynamic_info: Python supports negative indexes. Index -1 refers to the last character of the string, -2 to the one before it.

types_list.desc: Returns a single character by its index.
Returns a part of the string from start to end, excluding end.
Takes characters from the beginning up to the given index.
Takes characters from the given index to the end of the string.
Creates a copy of the entire string.
Takes characters using the specified step.
Completely reverses the string.

slides.title: Indexes
slides.text: The first character always has index 0.

strings_index.pro_tip: Slices are one of the most powerful tools for working with strings.
strings_index.warning: Accessing a non-existing index raises an IndexError.

strings_methods.name: String methods
strings_methods.definition: String methods are built-in Python functions that allow you to modify, analyze, and check text. All methods are called using a dot after the string.
strings_methods.dynamic_info: All string methods return a NEW string and do not modify the original one.

types_list.desc: Converts all letters to uppercase.
Converts all letters to lowercase.
Makes the first letter of the string uppercase.
Capitalizes the first letter of each word.
Removes spaces at the beginning and end of the string.
Removes spaces only from the left side.
Removes spaces only from the right side.
Replaces one part of the string with another.
Splits the string into a list.
Joins a list of strings into one string.
Returns the index of a character or -1.
Counts how many times a value appears.
Checks if the string starts with a value.
Checks if the string ends with a value.
Returns True if the string contains only digits.
Returns True if the string contains only letters.
Returns True if the string contains only letters and digits.

slides.title: String methods
slides.text: Methods are called using a dot and parentheses.

strings_methods.pro_tip: Methods can be chained one after another.
strings_methods.warning: Do not forget the parentheses () — without them the method will not work.

lists_basics.name: Lists in Python
lists_basics.definition: A list is a data type called list that is used to store multiple values in one variable. A list can contain numbers, strings, and even other lists. Elements are ordered and have indexes.
lists_basics.dynamic_info: Lists are mutable, which means you can add, remove, and change elements after creation.

types_list.desc: Creates a list with three numbers.
Creates an empty list.

lists_basics.pro_tip: Lists are one of the most used data types in Python.

lists_methods.name: List methods
lists_methods.definition: List methods allow you to add, remove, sort, and modify elements. Methods are called using a dot.
lists_methods.dynamic_info: Most methods modify the original list.

types_list.desc: Adds an element to the end.
Inserts an element at index.
Adds elements from another list.
Removes first matching element.
Removes and returns element.
Removes all elements.
Returns element index.
Counts occurrences.
Sorts ascending.
Sorts by rule.
Sorts descending.
Reverses order.
Creates a copy.

lists_methods.pro_tip: sort() and reverse() modify the list.
lists_methods.warning: remove() fails if element is missing.

lists_functions.name: Functions for lists
lists_functions.definition: Functions help analyze and process lists.

types_list.desc: Number of elements.
Finds smallest value.
Finds largest value.
Adds all numbers.
Checks if element exists.
Iterates elements.
Iterates with index.
Creates list from string.
Numbers from 0 to 4.
Does not change original.

lists_slices.name: List slices
lists_slices.definition: Slices allow you to get parts of a list.

types_list.desc: Full copy.
From 0 to 2.
From index 2.
From 1 to 3.
Every second element.
Start with step.
Range with step.
Reverses list.
From 5 to 2.

lists_nested.name: Nested lists
lists_nested.definition: A list can contain other lists. Used for tables and matrices.

types_list.desc: Two-dimensional list.
Three-dimensional structure.
